title: How to Arrange Roses

parts.name: Trimming the Roses and Preparing the Vase

steps.headline: Spread out the roses and position the buds so they’re at an even level.
steps.description: Work on a flat surface so you can easily see what you’re doing. Keep in mind that you may end up trimming some of the roses to be shorter than others, depending on the type of arrangement you create. Keep things classy with a monochrome arrangement or create a more visually varied one with multiple colors, like cream, yellow, and pink.

steps.headline: Trim the ends of the stems so they are even all the way across.
steps.description: Take a clean pair of scissors or pruning shears and cut off the bottom 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) of each stem. You don’t want to cut away too much of the length at the beginning of this process, but you do want to get rid of the hard ends. Once you get around to actually arranging the roses, you’ll trim them down further to fit better in the vase.

steps.headline: Rinse out the vase and fill it 3/4 full with fresh tap water.
steps.description:
If you’re using a glass vase, you may also want to clean the exterior to wipe away any smudges or fingerprints. Roses can be arranged beautifully in many different kinds of vases:
Use several small vases to decorate a long table or a mantle. Opt for a tall vase to accentuate a long, full arrangement. Create a stunning display in a short round or square vase. Use your imagination and repurpose an ordinary item for a vase, like a champagne bottle, a mason jar, or even a coffee mug.

steps.headline: Prune away the excess leaves and thorns that will be below water level.
steps.description: Hold up each rose to the vase and then cut away all the foliage that will hit below the water. Use scissors to cut the leaves off where they intersect with the stem, and use a pair of pruning shears or a thorn stripper to remove the thorns. Removing the leaves and thorns will keep the roses healthier for longer, plus it’ll make your arrangement look less crowded.Tip: Wear gardening gloves during this process to protect your hands from nicks and cuts.

steps.headline: Remove any brown or damaged petals from the roses.
steps.description: Visually examine each rose and pluck away any brown, dry, or torn petals from the buds. This is a simple step that can greatly improve the look of your arrangement! Pull the petal away from the bud where it connects at the base for the cleanest look.

steps.headline: Empty a packet of flower food into the water.
steps.description: Most of the time when you buy roses, you’ll get an accompanying packet of plant food. Cut the packet open and empty the contents in the water-filled vase. The flower food will keep your flowers fresh for longer.Try This Out: If the roses didn’t come with flower food, don’t despair! Instead, mix 2 tablespoons (30 mL) of white vinegar and 2 tablespoons (25 grams) of sugar into the water. The acid from the vinegar will combat bacteria and the sugar will encourage the roses to grow.

steps.headline: Add greenery or filler flowers to the arrangement for visual variety.
steps.description: Some popular greenery options are myrtle, leatherleaf fern, dusty miller, lemon leaf, eucalyptus, and grevillea. For filler flowers, look for statice, snapdragon, delphinium, bells of Ireland, baby’s breath, and feverfew. Follow the same steps you did for the roses. Cut the ends of the greenery so they’re all even, and trim away the leaves that will hit below water level. You don’t have to add anything else to your arrangement, but greenery and filler flowers can make it look fuller and can be fun to play around with.

steps.headline: Trim the ends of the stems at a diagonal as you place each rose in the vase.
steps.description: In general, the roses that are on the outside of the arrangement should be 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) shorter than the ones that will be in the center. The buds of the tallest roses should extend 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) above the rim of the vase, while the shorter, exterior roses should extend 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm). Cutting the stems at a diagonal helps them drink water more efficiently than if they were to remain cut straight across.

steps.headline: Crisscross the stems of the roses as you fill the vase.
steps.description: Add one rose to the vase at a time. Create a grid by placing the roses around the edges of the vase. For example, place the first rose into the vase so that the stem near the bud is touching one side while the end of the same stem is hitting the opposite side of the vase. Then do the same with a second rose exactly opposite the first one you placed. Remember to place the shorter roses around the exterior of the arrangement and the longer roses in the center.Tip: If the roses look too loose, try arranging them in a plastic cup inside the vase. This will limit the amount of space and can help your arrangement stay together. If you’re working with a clear or glass vase, this option won’t work.

steps.headline: Add the greenery to your arrangement.
steps.description: Trim the greenery to be roughly the same height as the roses and cut the ends at an angle. Place the greenery amongst the roses and around the edges, taking care to space it out evenly so the arrangement looks balanced. Remember that you can always trim and rearrange the roses and greenery as you go! Take your time and step back every once and a while to view your arrangement from a distance and make sure it looks even.

steps.headline: Fluff the flowers by gently lifting them and setting them back down.
steps.description: Gently grasp the arrangement underneath the buds, lift the entire thing 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm), and then lower it back down. This lets the roses reposition themselves to fill extra space in a natural way. Fill any new gaps with more greenery or reposition a rose if necessary.
